educational_objective: Diagnose megaloblastic anemia on a peripheral blood smear.
question_text: A 66-year-old woman is evaluated for anemia.Peripheral blood smear is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: This peripheral blood smear is compatible with megaloblastic anemia (Option C). A hypersegmented neutrophil (more than five distinct lobes) is present and supports the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia. The presence of oval-shaped enlarged erythrocytes (macro-ovalocytes) further suggests megaloblastic anemia. Causes include folate deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, and exposure to drugs affecting folate metabolism and/or DNA synthesis. Because megaloblastic causes of anemia affect trilineage hematopoiesis, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia may accompany anemia.
